conclusion: Analyze the forces acting on the system to determine the minimum force F at point D to keep rope CD horizontal.
A weight of mass m is suspended at point C, exerting a downward force FT = mg.
Ropes AC and BC are inclined and support the weight at C, with tensions having vertical and horizontal components.
A force F must be applied at point D to keep rope CD horizontal, counteracting horizontal components of tensions in ropes AC and BC.
Ropes AC and BC are of length L, horizontal distance between A and B is 2L, forming an isosceles triangle.
Vertical height from ceiling to point C is h = sqrt(3)L/2 using Pythagorean theorem.
Vertical components of tensions in ropes AC and BC must balance downward force FT = mg: TA sinθ + TB sinθ = mg.
Substitute sinθ: TA sqrt(3)/2 + TB sqrt(3)/2 = mg.
Since TA = TB, let T = TA = TB, then T sqrt(3) = mg implies T = mg/sqrt(3).
Horizontal components of tensions TA and TB must be balanced by force F at D: F = TA cosθ + TB cosθ.
Substitute cosθ and TA = TB = T: F = T/2 + T/2 = T.
The minimum force F at point D to keep rope CD horizontal is F = mg/sqrt(3).
